Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the behavior of microscopic particles. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is partly because it is based on a mathematical formalism that is unfamiliar to many people. In this paper, we provide a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is based on a familiar mathematical structure: Hilbert spaces. We show that quantum mechanics is equivalent to a certain category of operators on Hilbert spaces. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is based on a familiar mathematical structure.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. This increase in demand will be accompanied by a 2 °C increase in global mean temperature by the end of the century. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the world’s major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, despite decades of research, we still do not know how diverse assemblages of LMH partition food resources. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that LMH partition food resources in a variety of ways, including differential consumption of grasses versus nongrasses and spatiotemporal stratification in use of different parts of the same plant. Nonetheless, LMH diversity was not linked to plant diversity, suggesting that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need to consider the taxonomic resolution of diet data when studying the coexistence of LMH. This will be critical for understanding the role of LMH in the conservation of African savanna biodiversity. (PsycINFO Database Record

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the crisis is still in its early stages, and many businesses expect to remain open for the foreseeable future. We also find that many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses are planning to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean has become a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the universe. The solar system formed 4.6 Ga ago, but the origin of the solar system is still a mystery. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar cosmic ray exposure ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result provides a new constraint for the origin of the solar system. It also provides a new constraint for the formation of the first stars and the origin of the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of life. In humans, the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. In other species, such as dogs and cats, the ability to reproduce is limited by the amount of food available to the mother. Here, we show that the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power in all species studied. We also show that the ability to reproduce is increased in species that practice allonursing. This suggests that the mother’s metabolic power is the primary limiting factor on reproduction in placental mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn in the brain. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. This study also opens the door to the use of VX-765 in other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is responsible for controlling vascular tone, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulating the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is able to control each function using a network of cells that are specialized to detect specific stimuli. This network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected by a network of short paths. The network is also highly synchronizable, which allows for rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells. These findings reveal the design of the endothelial network and its role in controlling cardiovascular activity. Understanding the design of the endothelial network is important for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are extracted from a variety of sources, including deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to a wide range of stakeholders.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this second Threonine residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the absence of this coupling. Finally, it provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter that is observed during the closing of the activation gate. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be shaped by the presence of a diverse array of microorganisms. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is an active area of research, and the search for novel bioactive compounds produced by the microbiome is a growing field. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tracts of herbivores. These fungi are a previously understudied group of microorganisms that could be a source of novel bioactive compounds. This study provides a foundation for future research into the natural products of anaerobic fungi and their potential applications.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to precisely control the mechanical response of a device is critical for its functionality. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of a specific structure are often limited in achieving the desired response. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to digitally synthesize composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The synthesized structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of programmable mechanical devices with complex and extreme responses.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we investigated the role of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the heterochronic let-7 pathway. We found that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is down-regulated in the fetal versus adult hematopoietic system. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of effective therapies is a major challenge. Cancer cells often exhibit metabolic changes that contribute to resistance to therapy and promote tumor growth. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), which are downstream targets of SREBP1. We also found that SREBP1 and SCD1 are frequently up-regulated in cancer and contribute to ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Finally, we demonstrated that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with heart failure, which is a major cause of hospitalization in the United States. We show that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which promotes vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that caution should be taken against the use of these drugs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP’s effects on bird populations are complex and not as straightforward as expected. The policy halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has not yet been sufficient to reverse declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems on federal land may be a step in the wrong direction for older forests and bird conservation.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for the treatment of infections caused by antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, all of which may have important implications for health and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1.0- to 1.2-degree drop in global temperature, which is hypothesized to be caused by one or more bolide impacts. The bolide impact hypothesis is supported by varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules at the YDB. However, the origin of the magnetic grains and microspherules is unclear. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are terrestrial in origin. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. This suggests that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of extraterrestrial origin and that the bolide impact hypothesis is valid.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the expression of CTLA-4 in adult mice is essential for the development of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. We further show that CTLA-4 expression in Treg cells is essential for their suppressive function. However, CTLA-4 expression in T cells is dispensable for their suppressive function. Thus, CTLA-4 expression in Treg cells is essential for their suppressive function, whereas CTLA-4 expression in T cells is dispensable for their suppressive function.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin and diversification of beetles remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population was more important than the number of models in the population. This suggests that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that participates in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also show that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may accelerate the rate of AD neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes and suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a molecular basis for the differential risk of APOE4 for AD. They also suggest that APOE4 may be associated with an increased risk for other neurodegenerative diseases.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is the densest part of the Earth, and it is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the outer core. The inner core is a unique part of the Earth that has been studied for more than 100 y. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the current understanding. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and the Earth. It also provides a new approach to understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This study may lead to a better understanding of the Earth and its evolution.

The brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels, is a promising measure of the reactivity of the brain to DA stimulation. We found that compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability. In ventral striatum (key brain reward region), MP-induced reductions in DVs and BPND (reflecting DA increases) were inversely correlated with scores of negative emotionality, which were significantly higher for marijuana abusers than controls. In marijuana abusers, DA responses in ventral striatum were also inversely correlated with addiction severity and craving. The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal DVs, might contribute to their negative emotionality (increased stress reactivity and irritability) and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the importance of studying the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation in marijuana abusers.

Language is the most complex behavior we know of. How the human brain processes language is therefore one of the most pressing questions in cognitive neuroscience. We here show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict brain and behavior in this domain with similar accuracy. This provides computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s comprehension of natural language. The same models also outperform humans on a predictive language task. These results have implications for theories of language evolution and acquisition, and for the design of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property, but rather a phenomenon that is specific to DL. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a NN. This result implies a classification theory of conditions under which one can compute a stable NN with a given accuracy by an algorithm. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This result implies that the instability of DL is not a general property, but rather a phenomenon that is specific to DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 years. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study’s conclusion was widely accepted. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research. However, the cause of a reactional condition known as Lucio's phenomenon, which is similar to lepromatous leprosy, has remained elusive. Here we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a leprosy pathogen that causes a distinct clinical condition. The genomes of M. lepromatosis and M. leprae are similar in size and gene content, and the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two pathogens have retained many of the same virulence factors and that they are still capable of causing similar diseases. This study also provides a phylogeographic survey of leprosy, which will be useful for future studies of the epidemiology of leprosy. (PsycINFO Database Record

The emergence of thermodynamics from quantum dynamics is a central problem in quantum physics. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in this process, but its exact computation is a formidable task. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and show that it holds for a wide class of integrable models. Our work opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 500,000 deaths in the United States alone. The only vaccine currently available is the Pfizer–BioNTech vaccine, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This vaccine is not suitable for mass vaccination programs. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. This vaccine is highly attenuated in vivo, resulting in mild disease and reduced weight loss in hamsters. Importantly, the vaccine generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies and is protective in a relevant hamster model. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. Thus, it may be a valuable addition to the arsenal of COVID-19 vaccines. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the Black Death, which caused the pandemic, is still debated. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death, ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using Bayesian inference to model mortality data. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not a single epidemic but a series of epidemics, with the first one being the most severe. This finding is important for understanding the history of plague in Europe and the world.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic of study in comparative neurobiology. However, to understand the evolution of brain power, we need to look at the number of neurons in the brain, not just at the size of the skull. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and show that the evolution of brain size in reptiles is not representative of the evolution of brain power. We also show that the evolution of brain size in birds and mammals is not only a consequence of the evolution of cognitive ability but also of the evolution of brain density. These findings have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is thought to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF-induced torque on filaments is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filaments. We propose that this mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of ADF in cell migration and cancer metastasis. They also provide a general mechanism for understanding the role of torque in molecular motors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose versus glucose remain unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. Further, the findings suggest that the brain may be a potential target for interventions aimed at reducing food intake. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments but is controversial in real-world settings. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook, and that this influence is not limited to in-person interaction. This work suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ negative experiences can lead to negative emotions.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and nonprotein-coding RNAs are involved in a wide range of cellular processes. One of the most common modifications found in coding RNAs is the pseudouridine (Ψ) modification, which is present in 10–20% of all uridine nucleotides. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a profound impact on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for our understanding of the regulation of nonprotein-coding RNAs and the translation of mRNA in health and disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. These associations are robust to a range of sensitivity analyses, and longitudinal analyses indicate that higher worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We use a quantitative approach to test the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a common size of ∼500 kg by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. The existence of this size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results provide a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in mammals and suggest that the aquatic environment may be a major driver of the evolution of body size in other vertebrates.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and most rhinovirus isolates replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that rhinovirus replication was enhanced at 37 °C, and that this temperature-dependent growth phenotype was dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of rhinovirus temperature-dependent growth and may help to explain the increased susceptibility to rhinovirus infection at cool temperatures. (PsycINFO Database Record

The type IV pili of bacteria are surface-exposed appendages that are used for a variety of functions, including twitching motility, biofilm formation, and surface attachment. Here we show that type IV pili are also used by the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa as a mechanosensitive sensor. This mechanosensitive surface attachment system is regulated by a chemosensory system that detects the mechanical activity of the pili. This system is important for the pathogen because it allows it to sense the mechanical activity of the surface it is growing on, which in turn regulates the expression of genes involved in virulence and biofilm formation. This work demonstrates that type IV pili are used by bacteria as sensors for mechanical activity, and that this system is important for the regulation of bacterial virulence.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this has led to increasing contamination of surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and how this contamination depends on the age of the pesticide and the stringency of environmental regulations. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This risk is highest in countries with the least stringent environmental regulations and for newer-generation pesticides. These results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animal populations has been a major concern, as it could lead to the emergence of new variants that are more transmissible or virulent. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and could serve as a reservoir for the virus. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2, as well as the role of animals in the transmission and persistence of the virus. This knowledge is critical for developing effective strategies to mitigate the risk of spillback to humans and to minimize the impact of the pandemic on animal populations.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. Although the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is well established, the contribution of other components of the amyloid cascade, such as soluble Aβ, is less clear. Here, we show that soluble Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors that trigger microglial activation and contribute to the development of neuroinflammation in AD. Our findings suggest that soluble Aβ may be a critical factor in the pathogenesis of AD, and that targeting this component may be a viable therapeutic strategy.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for understanding the role of this species in the development of human societies. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is to be found in the Hellenistic period at the site of Maresha, Israel. We show that the frequency of chicken bones at Maresha is exceptionally high, and that the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones is a result of the high frequency of adult individuals. We further argue that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. (Abridged)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows us to study the folding of a large protein at high resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a polyglobular state, which is followed by a slower formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway and is the site of three destabilizing mutations. The intermediate is also the site of a second step of folding that is not yet understood. These results provide a new level of understanding of the folding of large proteins. They also suggest that the folding of proteins is more complex than previously thought. (Abridged)

The accumulation of RNA in cells experiencing stress is a well-known phenomenon. In bacteria, this RNA is often capped with a dinucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) moiety, which is thought to be important for their function. However, the predominant decapping enzyme ApaH is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is not normally active in these conditions, becomes the predominant decapping enzyme in the presence of disulfide stress. We demonstrate that RppH preferentially decapps Np4-capped RNAs, generating a monophosphorylated RNA 5′ terminus that is required for rapid degradation of the transcript. Our findings suggest that the decapping of Np4-capped RNAs may be a more general mechanism for regulating gene expression in response to stress.

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for developing new strategies to treat sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global, quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, despite external perturbations. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity levels, and are found in a variety of natural and man-made systems. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, which can be used to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new route to control the properties of diamond and opens up new opportunities for its applications.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of animals is less clear. Here, we show that the evolution of the immune system in animals was driven by the evolution of plant-associated microorganisms. We also show that the immune system of animals evolved to recognize plant-associated microorganisms as pathogens and to respond to them with antimicrobial peptides. We further show that the antimicrobial peptides of animals are structurally similar to the antimicrobial peptides of plants. This suggests that the evolution of the immune system in animals was driven by the evolution of plant-associated microorganisms. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of the immune system in animals and the origin of the antimicrobial peptides of animals and plants. It also provides a basis for the development of antimicrobial peptides as a new class of drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the molecular “hand-off” between males and females is a key component of reproductive success. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that female-derived proteins become associated with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of mutations in VWF, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the single molecule data are not artifacts of the bulk phase. These results provide a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF and may be relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. Continuous observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. Our ACI analysis shows increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of reconstructed ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (PsycINFO Database Record

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a complex process that requires the parasite to overcome a number of physical barriers. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. We show that the malaria parasite binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and that this interaction alters the red cell’s biophysical properties, including an increase in the cytoskeletal tension and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. These changes in the red cell are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. (PsycINFO Database Record

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, which can be used to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond for applications in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of seasonal influenza outbreaks. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neurophysiological data. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words merge into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system that is shared by all humans.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions and tissue patterning. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a unique opportunity to understand the mechanisms of gene redundancy and the regulation of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable manner. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis could be used to deliver nitrogen in a sustainable manner in agriculture and in the restoration of nitrogen-poor ecosystems. (Less)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is fundamental to all animals. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals.

We estimate the climate and public health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We show that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51 °C, which can be moderated to 0.36 °C by reducing tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This is a major contribution to the current debate on climate change and public health.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the development of a subunit vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is a promising approach. However, the production of such vaccines at large scale is challenging, and the current vaccines are not suitable for low- and middle-income countries. Here we report an engineered RBD that is suitable for large-scale production and exhibits enhanced immunogenicity compared to the current vaccines. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which may further enhance the immunogenicity. These findings provide a promising platform for a global vaccine supply. The ligand–receptor interaction between secreted small ALKAL proteins and human ALK/LTK family receptors is implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues. In the zebrafish Danio rerio, the ALK/LTK family members are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. We show that zebrafish ALK/LTK family members activate zebrafish ALK/LTK family members in vivo and that loss-of-function alleles of zebrafish ALK/LTK family members cause iridophore loss. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development. This is an important step toward understanding the role of ALK/LTK family receptors in human neuroblastoma. Furthermore, our findings suggest that ALK/LTK family receptors may be promising targets for the treatment of neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague from its progenitor, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, is a key event in the history of the genus Yersinia. The study of ancient plague genomes has revealed the emergence of the plague pathogen, but the number of genomes recovered is too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 plague genomes from Eurasia dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which allowed us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also provide a framework for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. (PsycINFO Database Record

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate change science. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage in North American Mollisols. These results are consistent with a meta-analysis of published studies comparing the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on Mollisols worldwide. We also show that the addition of legumes and manure to annual cropping systems enhanced soil microbial biomass and C-use efficiency but did not significantly increase MAOM-C or total SOC storage. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. Our findings suggest that the restoration of grasslands and the adoption of soil health management practices that integrate livestock could be critical for mitigating climate change.
