The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread in humans. We used this framework to identify SARS-CoV-2 as a spillover risk, and to identify other viruses that may also pose a threat. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the type of pollinator attracted to the plant. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. We also identify a previously undescribed enzyme that is necessary for the production of the red pigment. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in attracting pollinators. (Less)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from the late 5th/early 6th century AD from present-day Bavaria, Germany. The data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and pathogenesis of MERS-CoV. They also suggest that the development of a vaccine against bat coronaviruses is urgently needed

We describe a large-scale, resource-scarce, mNGS-based pathogen surveillance study in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce Southeast Asia is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study demonstrates the value of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential for mNGS-based pathogen surveillance to improve public health. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in the nucleus by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme, which is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of PCNA in DNA replication and repair. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but it has not been possible to replicate proteins with RNA. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA, amplify RNA, and synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including functional RNA molecules. This represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is effective in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results provide a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper levels is therefore important for their survival. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper. Copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC products were demonstrated in coculture experiments with a variety of human pathogenic fungi and bacteria. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the role of natural products in fungal interactions with other organisms. (PsycINFO Database Record

The formation of silica polymorphs in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism. The amorphous silica is precipitated from variable aqueous solutions and/or their diagenesis products. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of woody plants to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the contribution of Th17 cells to the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model, indicating that they require the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells to induce disease. Th17 cells also supported the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different causes and different rates of progression. There is a need for a disease model that recapitulates the disease in a highly reproducible manner. We now report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which can be expanded in culture and used to model the disease. This method will enable high-throughput screening of compounds to identify those that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of A. phagocytophilum to colonize the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to enhance its transmission to humans. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of the avian tail is a key event in the origin of modern flight and the diversification of birds. The study of the early history of the pygostyle has been hindered by the limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This taxon adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group and provides insights into the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. (Less)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of green colors in plants. Our results have implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates and plants, and for the development of new technologies for color detection. (Less)

Cancer stem cells are thought to be responsible for metastasis and relapse in breast cancer. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates m6A in NANOG mRNA, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) marker. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways. ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of BCSCs, phenocopying the effect of hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment may contribute to the maintenance of BCSCs and the development of relapse in breast cancer.

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter in understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. The age model for the extinction is based on a new U-Pb zircon age model for the Global Stratotype Section and Point at Meishan, China. The age model is based on five volcanic ash beds that define a precise chronology for the extinction and its aftermath. The age model provides a basis for a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model also establishes an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will be a valuable tool for future research on the Permian-Triassic extinction and its aftermath. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is not well understood. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development. We have determined the cryo-electron microscopy structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, in a conformation that is consistent with the high infectivity of the virus. We also determined the structure of the spike in complex with the human antibody that binds to the D614G mutant spike. The structure of the D614G mutant spike suggests that this mutation may increase infectivity.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are fundamental to understanding the properties of matter. The chemical properties of atoms are also the basis of the periodic table, which is the most powerful tool in chemistry. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and we propose a new way of thinking about the periodic table. We also show that the periodic table is not a mere coincidence, but a consequence of the chemical properties of atoms.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been a major driver of global fire activity, and that these are likely to continue to play a role in shaping future fire regimes. However, we also show that climate change has been a major driver of global fire activity in the past, and that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks may be able to mitigate some of the warming caused by human ignitions. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the role of fire in climate change mitigation.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a symbiont population in a specific symbiosis. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the animal is active and the symbiont is producing light. This glycan-induced modulation of symbiont activity may be a general strategy used by animals to control the activities of their symbionts.

The study of text data has become a central part of many disciplines. However, the analysis of text data is challenging because of the complexity of the data and the diversity of the applications. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We show that our method can be applied to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data from many domains. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and can be extended to other types of data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and suggests that the disease was not introduced into Europe in a single event, but rather in a series of events, each of which was preceded by a climate-driven

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a major prey item for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has been described as a mass wasting event. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of this disease. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids. The discovery of this virus in museum specimens suggests that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. This densovirus could be a major threat to the ecosystem and to fisheries.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that the antibody can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the impact of the demographic events on the present

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing a wealth of information on crop status and condition. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily used for quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural monitoring and forecasting systems. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources such as forests and water.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. Our model is based on a simple idea: information is stored in the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for studying the evolution of photosynthetic organisms. However, the evolutionary history of plastids is still poorly understood, and the molecular signatures of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle are not known. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the extent of functional reduction, and that the molecular evolution of plastid genes is shaped by the macroevolutionary events of the transition to parasitism. This model can be used to infer the evolutionary history of plastids and to understand the molecular evolution of the genes that are retained in the parasitic plastids. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in South Africa and globally. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the role of anthropogenic climate change in the probability of such droughts in the future. We find that the probability of such a drought will increase by a factor of five to six by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the probability of such a drought will increase by a factor of five to six by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they form are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals form and the time at which they formed.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the so-called isopteroic ring, is a key reaction in this pathway. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, to catalyze this reaction, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria use a diiron protein, AcsF. The latter is the catalytic component of a larger enzyme complex, which is O2-dependent. Here we show that the diiron protein is a subunit of the O2-dependent enzyme, and that the [4Fe-4S] cluster protein is a subunit of the O2-independent enzyme. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the O2-dependent cyclase enzymes in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria. (Abridged)

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is associated with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a mouse model of multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is characterized by the activation of microglia and astrocytes, which are the main source of proinflammatory mediators. Neuroinflammation is also associated with apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1), a kinase that is activated by proinflammatory stimuli. However, the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remains unclear. Here, we show that ASK1 is required for neuroinflammation in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes in EAE. We further show that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased substantially in recent decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human-caused climate change. This finding is important because it suggests that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions will continue to increase in the future. This increase will likely lead to more acute human and ecosystem impacts.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. The identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms is challenging because of the complexity of the disorder. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis and a target for drug development. Mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SO channel, ORAI1, or in the Ca2+ sensor of the SO channel, STIM1, result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the SO channel, which result in hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates causes pathology in a manner that is dependent on endocytosis. These findings provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the mechanisms underlying this spreading may be a potential therapeutic strategy.

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses is a major concern in the current era of climate change and globalization. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by inhibiting leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is responsible for the hydrolysis of leukotriene-A4 to leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune response of the host and the role of LTA4H in the immune response of the pathogen. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth and proliferation. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We have shown that these inhibitors block cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We have also shown that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer with a poor prognosis. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT as a cancer therapy. It also provides a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by the aggregation of mutant proteins that are not normally present in the nervous system. We show that the proteins that are present in inclusion bodies in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. This suggests that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in many-body physics, quantum optics, and photonic crystals.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants, including the origin of the flowering plants. The Cretaceous is also a time of great interest for the origin of life, as it is the first period in which the fossil record is rich enough to allow the study of the evolution of plants. The Cretaceous is also a time of great interest for the origin of flowering plants, as it is the first period in which the fossil record is rich enough to allow the study of the evolution of flowering plants. The research presented here focuses on the Cretaceous flowering plant Montsechia, which is the oldest known flowering plant. The study of Montsechia raises questions about the origin of flowering plants and the role of aquatic habitats in the origin of flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Abridged)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we provide a precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is in agreement with the rate predicted by climate models. This estimate is based on a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data, which is the longest such time series available. The results presented here provide a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise than previous studies, and they are consistent with the rate predicted by climate models.

Pain is a major public health problem, with the elderly reporting more pain than today’s midlife. However, the elderly report less pain than today’s midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that each successive birth cohort has more pain than the previous cohort, and that this pattern is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this pattern continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme catalysis is a central theme in structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions, provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity. This detailed picture of the intermediate and its reaction pathway is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole does not react, while the isostere benzimidazole does not react. The study of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate and its reaction pathway is a key step in understanding the mechanism of action of these enzymes and their potential as drug targets. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity. (Abridged version.)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum antiviral that has shown efficacy against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This model has been used to study the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV infection, and has been shown to be a suitable model for testing antiviral treatments. The data presented here will be useful in the design of a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS-CoV infection. (PsycINFO Database Record

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-mediated regulation of symbiont activity may be a general strategy used by animals to control the activities of their associated microbes.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools by 50%. This is a major public health intervention that can be implemented in schools across the United States. The study also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline. This is a scalable intervention that can be implemented in schools across the United States.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain largely unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that RNA polymerase II (pol II) stalls at alkylated DNA template and that the stalling is exacerbated by the proofreading activity of pol II. We further identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II that is involved in modulating the translocation of alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first proteolytic steps. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a critical determinant of MERS-CoV tropism. The first proteolytic steps may also be important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria can have a large impact on meal selection. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in other settings. We also show that the impact of this intervention was not limited to the cafeteria in which it was implemented. This suggests that it could be easily replicated in other settings. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. This is an important step toward achieving the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We apply quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a proof-of-principle for the application of AI-ETD for glycoproteomics. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We also find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect the share of voters who report that they are likely to vote by mail in the future. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is unlikely to have a large impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease it causes. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, suggesting that it may be important for the unique immune evasion and/or immune suppression activities of this protein. This work provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are “strong” and “significant.” But what does it mean to be strong and significant? We describe a new way of thinking about this. We call it “selective inference.” It is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring a strong association. This is important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We illustrate the new approach with three examples: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still challenging. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be extended to the generation of other types of ECs, such as hepatic ECs. This approach may be useful for the treatment of liver diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are involved in a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish possess three genes that encode ligands for ALK and LTK. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a type of photoreceptor that is found in the eyes and fins of zebrafish. Our results establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are required for the differentiation of neural crest-derived cells into iridophores. These findings provide insights into the role of RTKs in zebrafish pigmentation and may lead to the identification of new targets for the treatment of human cancers.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function, leading to glucose intolerance. Mechanistically, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of virions. The influenza A genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results suggest that the influenza A genome can promote the selective packaging of the viral genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This network might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings could lead to the development of new strategies for the control of influenza A viruses. (PsycINFO Database Record

The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been extensively studied. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. Here, we demonstrate that disturbed flow activates YAP/TAZ in the endothelium to promote the atheroprone phenotypes and the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has led to substantial economic and ecological costs, and has increased the risk of wildfire to communities and infrastructure. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires. We show that human-caused wildfires have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has been largely driven by human activities. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of ignitions, and increasing management in regions where human-caused wildfires are dominant.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.
