Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The cause of bleaching is the overheating of zooxanthellae, which is often attributed to the direct effects of global warming. However, our results show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by the host’s metabolic response to heat stress, which in turn is driven by altered nutrient cycling. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that plays a central role in host–microbe interactions. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and many die from the disease. The identification of mechanisms that contribute to the development of resistance to therapy may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Here we show that the activation of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 contributes to the development of resistance to chemotherapy in breast cancer. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can be used to target ROR1 in breast cancer and that this antibody may improve the response to chemotherapy. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, a small volcano in West Antarctica, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This unique volcanic event is the only known event that could plausibly link the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation to stratospheric ozone depletion. This finding has implications for the interpretation of the timing of the onset of accelerated deglaciation and for the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate system. It also provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can impact the climate system. (Abridged)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where food security is low. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to provide food security and where biodiversity is most at risk from overfishing. Our findings underscore the need for improved management of inland fisheries to protect both food security and biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide with a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is realized. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the nervous system. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate after injury is not a property of the nervous system that evolved later, but rather a property that was present in the evolution of the nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions experiencing no recombination at all. We also find that recombination rates tend to be higher near the start of genes, and that the rates fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity, within genes. These results suggest that the distribution of recombination across the genome of Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interconnected regions. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the DMN. In contrast, in PD, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the DMN was deactivated during task performance in healthy subjects and early PD patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. The existence of 5′ cap-like structures on RNAs other than tRNA and rRNA has been suggested, but their existence has not been proven. We show that 5′ NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This 5′ NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This suggests that 5′ NAD+ RNA could modulate mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at certain loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the metabolic memory phenomenon.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato fruit flavor is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Less)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are more severe when species diversity is low. This is because more diverse communities are more likely to include species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. This is particularly important for species that are already experiencing thermal stress, as is the case for many species in the Anthropocene.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub for navigation, and its neurons are thought to form a map of local space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main neurons involved in forming a map of local space, are strongly coupled among themselves but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings suggest that grid cells might form a network that is largely distinct from those of other cell types. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and their functional roles in navigation. It also provides a platform for future studies of the neural basis of navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental factors. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that flowering can be a highly regulated process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental factors.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized type of neuronal integration in the dopamine-containing nigro system. This is a bouquet-like arborization of striosomal neurons that forms a highly specialized integration unit with dopamine-containing dendrites and afferents. This integration unit is likely to be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for regulating heart rate. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, called SAN cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining heart rate in the face of changes in blood pressure and other hemodynamic signals. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. Our results reveal that STIM1 regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs by linking the content of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores with the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane. These studies provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function and may lead to the development of therapies for heart failure. (PsycINFO Database Record

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in silicon accumulation and by priming of jasmonate (JA)-mediated defense responses. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice from insect herbivores. This study also provides a basis for further exploration of the mechanisms underlying the interaction between Si and JA in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Abridged) (less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by sustained, elevated neural activity. However, other work has suggested that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a model where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability provides memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This neuronal memory mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, making it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. We demonstrate that it is also sensitive to the context of the current word, which is a key feature of language. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall and into plant cells. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the internalization and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can lead to harmful algal blooms and other ecological and economic impacts. We show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes, where they can fuel algal blooms. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small streams, which are often overlooked in watershed-scale assessments. This approach could be applied to other large lakes and other water bodies that are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network that is connected to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale steady state of the universe is biased toward rare combinations of initial conditions. We propose that the same mechanism may be at work in the chemical world.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of in silico and in vivo experiments to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and render cortical microcircuitry susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs and may help explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be a potential target for treatment of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2, which is thought to be the result of anthropogenic emissions. However, the impact of this increase on the Earth system is not well understood. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period and was accompanied by a massive injection of organic matter–derived carbon. We show that this event was likely caused by a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2, which in turn led to widespread seafloor anoxia. Our results suggest that the Earth system is likely to respond to anthropogenic CO2 emissions in a similar manner. Thus, understanding the impact of the past CO2 increase on the Earth system is critical for understanding the impact of anthropogenic CO2 emissions today.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a panacea for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The study of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a major focus of research. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus in most species, but in some species, multiple sex determination alleles interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two female- and two male-determining alleles interact to produce four possible sex classes. We find that polygenic sex determination produces modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits, and that the evolution or introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner creates additional axes of variation. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by a number of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive carbonyl species (RCS) that are generated by photooxidation of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) and photodegradation of lipofuscin. The role of iron (Fe) in these processes is not well understood. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP) reduces the photooxidation and photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light. DFP also reduces the photooxidation of A2E in the absence of light. These findings suggest that Fe is involved in the photooxidation and photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E. We also show that the Fe chelator DFP reduces the photooxidation of the bisretinoid A2E in the absence of light. These findings suggest that Fe is involved in the photooxidation of the bisretinoid A2E. Our findings also suggest that Fe may be involved in the photooxidation of other bisretinoids. Thus, Fe may be involved in the photooxidation of the bisretinoids that are responsible for the loss of photoreceptor cell viability in retinal degeneration.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understand the functioning of food webs. Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are a model system to study the evolution of predatory morphology, as they have a highly specialized mode of prey capture. We show that siphonophores have evolved to capture different prey types, and that these transitions are linked to the evolution of the morphology and mode of evolution of their tentacles. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure that has been the subject of intense study for over 200 y. The fossil record of the hominin hand is fragmentary, however, and there is a gap in the fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. This gap is well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology (shaped bifacial stone tools), and the origin of the human hand is a key component of the origin of this technology. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil and the associated archaeological record provide a window into the evolution of the human hand. This work also highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for this process. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that these compounds inhibit SHMT in cancer cells, and that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth. We also show that cancer cells that are defective in glycine import are uniquely sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT as a cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study provides evidence that deforestation can affect people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of a modeling approach that combines two-way fixed-effects regression analysis with covariate balancing generalized propensity score (CBGPS) weighting to make causal inferences. This approach could be used in other settings to test the causal effects of environmental change on people’s diets.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased global food production by 100% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend is a consequence of the increasing size of modern farm vehicles, which are now approaching the weight of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
